headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to Novellus’ second quarter 2010 earnings conference call. Just as a reminder, this call is being recorded today, July 12, 2010. I would now like to turn the conference over to Ms. Robin Yim of Novellus Systems. Please go
componenttext: Good day, everyone, and welcome to Novellus’ second quarter 2010 earnings conference call. Just as a reminder, this call is being recorded today, July 12, 2010. I would now like to turn the conference over to Ms. Robin Yim of Novellus Systems. Please go ahead.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining the Novellus Systems second quarter 2010 earnings conference call. Joining me on the call today are Rick Hill, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, and John Hertz, Vice President an
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining the Novellus Systems second quarter 2010 earnings conference call. Joining me on the call today are Rick Hill, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, and John Hertz, Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
Financial results for the second quarter 2010 were released on PR Newswire shortly after 1:00 PM Pacific Daylight Time. You can obtain a copy of the news release in the Investor Relations section of our website at novellus.com. Today’s earnings call contains forward-looking statements about Novellus’ business outlook, the future performance of Novellus, and our products and forecasts of key metrics for the third quarter of 2010.
Specific forward-looking statements include, but are not limited to, our expectations regarding the continued improvement of the economy and the markets in which we operate, including our customers’ CapEx spending; our expectations for improvement in operating efficiency, leverage and cash flow in the third quarter of 2010; and our intention to continue to improve on these areas. Our expected effective tax rate for fiscal 2010; our financial model, including expectations with respect to operating expenses, the forecasted bookings, shipment volume, revenue, gross margin, operating expense, and earnings per share target for the third quarter of 2010; and other unanticipated future events.
We caution you that forward-looking statements are projections and expectations regarding future events, which may involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from the results contemplated, including an inaccurate basis for our financial forecast.
Information concerning risks that could cause actual results to differ materially is contained in today’s press release and our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including our Form 10-K for fiscal 2009, our most recent Form 10-Q and our Form 8-K. Forward-looking statements are based on information as of today and we assume no obligation to update any of these statements.
John Hertz will begin today’s call with a review of the financial results for the second quarter. Then Rick Hill will discuss the state of the business and our industry outlook, followed by guidance for the third quarter of 2010, and then open the call for the question-and-answer session.
Now I’ll turn the call over to John.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Robin. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us for our second quarter 2010 earnings conference call. I’m pleased to announce another outstanding quarter where we met or exceeded our guidance and continue to improve on all key f
componenttext:
Thank you, Robin. Good afternoon, everyone, and thank you for joining us for our second quarter 2010 earnings conference call. I’m pleased to announce another outstanding quarter where we met or exceeded our guidance and continue to improve on all key financial metrics such as operating leverage, profitability and cash flow from operations. Before I get into the specifics, I’d like to preface my comments by stating that our Q2 actual and Q1 comparative results will be discussed on a GAAP basis.
So with that, second quarter 2010 bookings were $385 million, up 20%, which was at the midpoint of our mid-quarter update guidance range of up 15% to 25%. The quarter-over-quarter increase on orders was driven primarily by foundry, and we saw continued strength in memory and a broadening of the overall customer base.
Q2 shipments were $332 million, up 17% sequentially, and ended on the higher end of our mid-quarter update guidance range of $315 million to $335 million. Second quarter revenues were $321 million, which was up 16% sequentially, and came in just above the high end of our mid-quarter update guidance range of $300 million to $320 million.
Our second quarter revenues by geographic region are as follows. The United States, 24%; Greater China, 44%; Korea, 21%; Japan, 3%; Europe, 8%. Second quarter gross margin was 48.8%, up from 48.5% in Q1 2010 and at the midpoint of our guidance range of 48% to 50%. Operating expenses in the second quarter totaled $84 million, which was in line with our model, where we expect to apply 7% of every incremental shipment dollar to operating expenses.
Our Q2 effective tax rate was 15.7%, which is on the low end of our guidance of 15% to 20%. We currently expect our effective tax rate for the year to come in at the lower end of that range. Second quarter net income was $63 million or net margin of 19.7%, which resulted in fully diluted earnings per share of $0.66, which exceeded the mid-quarter update guidance range of $0.55 to $0.62. We exceeded guidance due to higher revenue, operating expense control, improved tax rate, and share repurchases.
Moving now to the balance sheet, we ended the quarter with $743 million in cash, short-term investments, and long-term investments, which included $114 million in restricted cash. That total was down $9 million from $752 million in the prior quarter. We generated $104 million in cash flow from operations in the first quarter, which was 32% of revenue. Net income included non-cash charges for depreciation and amortization of $10 million and stock compensation of $9 million.
Cash flow from operations was offset by stock buybacks, which totaled $107 million in the quarter. We purchased 4.4 million shares of stock for an all-in cost per share of $24.57. $681 million remains authorized for repurchase under our stock repurchase program, which expires in October 2011.
Accounts receivables decreased modestly in the second quarter to $153 million despite a healthy increase in shipment levels resulting in record low DSOs of 43 days, down from 50 days at the end of Q1 and better than our ongoing targeted range of 50 to 60 days. Inventory increased by approximately $20 million on a sequential basis as a result of higher shipment levels forecasted in the third quarter. Inventory turns remained unchanged from Q1 at 3.4 times.
In closing, Q2 was an outstanding quarter from a financial results perspective, as we demonstrated our operating leverage as revenue increased and our cash generation capability. And I look forward to reporting continued improvement in Q3.
That concludes by remarks. Now I’ll turn it over to Rick who will comment on the state of the business followed by third quarter guidance for our key financial metrics.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. First off, I would like to congratulate John on his promotion to CFO. Obviously, it must have been a good promotion since our financial results are so good. I’d like to also take a moment to acknowledge Jeff Benzing’s retirement after
componenttext:
Thank you, John. First off, I would like to congratulate John on his promotion to CFO. Obviously, it must have been a good promotion since our financial results are so good. I’d like to also take a moment to acknowledge Jeff Benzing’s retirement after 23 years. He did a great job as a Chief Administrative Officer, and of course, he will be with us through the end of the year as an advisor to me. Jeff has been an integral part of the company and he will be an integral part of the company over the next four years as he phases into his retirement.
Next, I’d like to talk a little bit about the major announcements that we have today. You may have seen earlier today that we announced our new SABRE 3D platform, and there are three launch applications announced today that includes the TSV application for through-silicon vias, a bump application for the packaging environment, and also the redistribution layer. I’m very happy with the productivity of our engineering organization, and I’ll talk about that a little bit more in the Q&A session.
As John outlined in his discussion, we had great overall operating results. We have improved on every key financial metric from operating leverage and profitability to cash flow generation. And we intend to continue our drive for more and more efficiency in the company. In addition, as he reported, we purchased in the quarter 4.4 million shares at an average price of $24.57 and year-to-date have purchased back about 5.1 million shares at an average price of $24.15.
Our headcount ended the quarter at a total of 2,594. That’s through June of 2010. Our inventories, while they were up in absolute dollars due to growing shipments, as a percent of our forward shipments, they continued to improve. DSOs are down due to great work on our field and finance organizations collection process, and our plant equipment is continued to be controlled and assets continued to reduce as we manage CapEx going forward. And our cash flow from operations was an absolute remarkable $104 million for the quarter, which we are very, very pleased with.
Now with that, I will give you an update on the overall business environment. The third party electronics revenue forecast was raised 12%, up from 9% on the heels of very strong demand for PCs, smart phones and consumer electronics. And we currently do not see that slowing at this time. Third party forecasts for semiconductor revenues were increased recently to 27% compared to 20% one quarter ago. And as I mentioned in our mid-quarter update in May, we saw upside to 30%. Based on our own market research, we think the rate for 2010 could be slightly higher rate of 30% to 35%.
Utilization levels for quarter two were 94% and are likely to edge up to about 96% in the third quarter due to increased demand and seasonality, particularly in the foundry activity. Both DRAM and NAND average selling prices held up in the second quarter due to tight supply and third-party forecast for DRAM and NAND prices for the back half of the year remain relatively unchanged with only modest decreases near the end of 2010. I’m not sure we will see those decreases. I, in fact, hope that we don’t, as that will continue to be another more solid sign for continued strong CapEx spending.
Due to the strength across our customer base, our forecast for CapEx growth in fiscal year 2010 is greater than the 83% currently forecast by industry sources. We believe that we will be able to outgrow the industry CapEx growth by our targeted 50% in fiscal year 2010. So overall, business is very good.
With that, here is our guidance for the third quarter. We expect bookings to be flat to up 10%. And you might remember that I forecast good strong bookings on the high side in the second quarter that we would see flat bookings in the third with continued second half growth over the first half. So we still expect the second half growth to be greater than the sum of the first half.
Second, shipments are forecasted to be up sequentially from $345 million to $375 million in the third quarter. Our revenue is forecasted in the third quarter up sequentially in the range of $335 million to $365 million. Our gross margin is forecasted to improve to 50%, plus or minus 1%. And the earnings per share is forecasted to be in the range of $0.72 to $0.90 per share.
Now that concludes my comments on the guidance for the third quarter. Now I’d like to open it up for any questions that you might have.

componenttextpreview: Hi. Thank you so much for taking my questions. First question for John, more of a near-term question. Can you walk us through what’s going on in terms of particularly gross margins? I know operating margins matter more, but gross margins, it seems like
componenttext: Hi. Thank you so much for taking my questions. First question for John, more of a near-term question. Can you walk us through what’s going on in terms of particularly gross margins? I know operating margins matter more, but gross margins, it seems like we kind of reached a little bit of a plateau on an incremental basis. You’ve hit the target model for 50%. And at the midpoint for next quarter, just wondering what are the puts and takes in terms of gross margin. And when you start to get more volume or capacity buys, do you see the potential here for better than 50% incremental drop through particularly in Q3 and Q4. And I have a quick follow-up.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. I think right now we are rated down a little bit by AG and a little bit of a product/customer mix in the semiconductor group for the second quarter. So, as volume does increase, we think there is a potential and we do see that increase going into th
componenttext: Okay. I think right now we are rated down a little bit by AG and a little bit of a product/customer mix in the semiconductor group for the second quarter. So, as volume does increase, we think there is a potential and we do see that increase going into the third quarter.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And a follow-up question here for Rick, since we are heading into Semicon West, I think last year during Semicon West, a lot of the industry management teams kind of pooh-poohed 450-millimeter. Just wondering when your layer fast-forward to today, i
componenttext: Okay. And a follow-up question here for Rick, since we are heading into Semicon West, I think last year during Semicon West, a lot of the industry management teams kind of pooh-poohed 450-millimeter. Just wondering when your layer fast-forward to today, if there has been any change in terms of that mindset and particularly any change in terms of the timetable being set by Intel, TSMC and Samsung. Thanks.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-12-2010
componenttextpreview: I think 450-millimeter remains an economic challenge for the equipment industry. There continues to be technology innovation, a lot of which you will hear about later this afternoon in our analyst session that we have, beginning at 4 o’ clock. So we hop
componenttext: I think 450-millimeter remains an economic challenge for the equipment industry. There continues to be technology innovation, a lot of which you will hear about later this afternoon in our analyst session that we have, beginning at 4 o’ clock. So we hope you’re there for that. And we do believe that technology is the way to drive down the cost in the near future. That being said, we can’t ever stop the drive for lower cost. So at some point in time, 450 will become a reality. I still think it’s a little ways off. There are some technological hurdles that we need to overcome. And what we don’t want to do is just barge ahead without a lot of forethought. Otherwise we risk taking down the entire industry. And so that’s been our position for quite some time. I know I was quoted in an article here about six months ago where I said there probably will be a time for 450. It’s just still a little ways out. I do believe it. Okay. Next question.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-12-2010

componenttext: Yes. Thanks for taking my question. Rick, I wanted to find out on your bookings guidance, the range of about $40 million, what needs to happen to get to the upper end of the guidance? Is it one customer or one segment that’s driving it?

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-12-2010
componenttextpreview: It’s not one customer or one segment. Obviously, we had a strong quarter this quarter. It is a function of what’s going to happen in our IAG business and how that grows as well as timing of bookings, whether they fall right at the end of the third qua
componenttext: It’s not one customer or one segment. Obviously, we had a strong quarter this quarter. It is a function of what’s going to happen in our IAG business and how that grows as well as timing of bookings, whether they fall right at the end of the third quarter or end of the fourth quarter because we do see facilities ready to bring on equipment beginning in the first quarter. And so it’s a matter of when those bookings fall. It’s just our best estimate at this time. But again, we see strength from the standpoint of our current belief is that the second half will be up over the first half. And so obviously, if we are flat this particular quarter, we’re going to - we have to be up a little bit in the fourth quarter we expect.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-12-2010

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Thank you, Rick. Congratulations on a strong EPS ride. A question on the buyback. This is a pretty big buyback. You have said in the past that you will opportunistic. And so, does this price give an indication of what you consider as an opportu
componenttext: Thank you. Thank you, Rick. Congratulations on a strong EPS ride. A question on the buyback. This is a pretty big buyback. You have said in the past that you will opportunistic. And so, does this price give an indication of what you consider as an opportunistic and will you be equally aggressive at the price levels you bought back at?

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-12-2010
componenttextpreview: It will be equally consistent in what I do relative to buybacks, and that’s all we say about the buybacks. But we’re optimistic about the opportunity for the company, both from the standpoint of leverage and earnings, with the product flow and what we
componenttext: It will be equally consistent in what I do relative to buybacks, and that’s all we say about the buybacks. But we’re optimistic about the opportunity for the company, both from the standpoint of leverage and earnings, with the product flow and what we’ve done from the standpoint of gaining efficiency in our product development group. I think when you see the products that we are introducing today, the significance of the technology to the industry overall, I believe we are enabling TSV technology at a cost people can start to make their transition with. There is just a lot of upside going forward. And there are certainly macroeconomic effects that I cannot control. That’s just the way it is. But what we can do is given those macroeconomic effects on the market, we can make sure our shareholders benefit from that.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. The second one on your book-to-bill ratio that has been positive, I mean, greater than one and you have been building the backlog even this quarter. When do you get to where you start consuming your backlog? Are we in that territory where you start
componenttext: Okay. The second one on your book-to-bill ratio that has been positive, I mean, greater than one and you have been building the backlog even this quarter. When do you get to where you start consuming your backlog? Are we in that territory where you start to level off in building with the backlog?

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I’m hoping it’s not for quite a while. I’m pretty bullish on the end market opportunities that are coming forward. I have talked about those several times. I’ve talked about - the term I’ve quoted is the dentrification for the global commu
componenttext:
Well, I’m hoping it’s not for quite a while. I’m pretty bullish on the end market opportunities that are coming forward. I have talked about those several times. I’ve talked about - the term I’ve quoted is the dentrification for the global communications infrastructure that’s going on right now. I think you’d see that playing out in companies like Cisco and Huawei in their tremendous growth. And that’s all silicon-enabled. You’d see also basically a PC cycle going on within the developed countries right now. As Microsoft transitions to Windows 7, that’s all really redoing an infrastructure that we haven’t seen upgraded since the mid-‘90s.
We’ve got public investments in IT infrastructure for security, cyber security and personal security, particularly in the travel market. And of course, we’ve got the emerging Chinese consumer, which continues to be a major factor in the overall market today. And we don’t see those fundamental end drivers stopping. And I think that as long as people are willing and continue to do commerce, I think semiconductors are going to be very, very successful. And we watch companies like Intel that leads the way, Cisco we look at, the TSMCs of the world. They have an eye on their customers. We’re watching our customers. And we think overall the trend is positive. I think everybody is cautious given those macroeconomic factors, but, hey, we’ve got to run a business like the world is going to - the sun is going to rise tomorrow morning and that’s what we are doing.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-12-2010
componenttextpreview: All right. Thank you, Rick. Thank you.
componenttext: All right. Thank you, Rick. Thank you.

componenttext: Hi, thanks for taking my questions. And a very nice quarter. Rick, your orders in 2Q, maybe I’m reading too much into it. The first time, you have not been able to hit your high end of the guidance since Q2 of last year. Maybe I’m reading too much into it. But can you comment on the segment that didn’t allow you to hit the high end of the guidance, our guidance in 2Q?

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think just historically when you look at this particular quarter, you have to think about what’s going on within our customer base and what they are busy working on. Right now, you’ve got to remember, what they are doing is building capacity o
componenttext: Well, I think just historically when you look at this particular quarter, you have to think about what’s going on within our customer base and what they are busy working on. Right now, you’ve got to remember, what they are doing is building capacity of which the second quarter they started to really apply that investment. That was coming on line. They really hit this next Christmas cycle and the back-to-school cycle that’s going on. And so there is just a slight pause here. But my expectation is when I see what’s lined up on the table, as long as end demand remains strong, which I think it will for the reasons I just defined a couple of seconds ago, you are going to see them come back into the market as they digest the equipment we sold and they are going to be pulling us to try to accelerate deliveries, thereby accelerating orders. And you will start to see, I think, a growth in the book again. You know, you’re right. I didn’t hit the very, very high end, but I’m still not dissatisfied at this juncture.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think what we would have seen would have been a weakening in the foundry, with a strengthening in the NAND Flash. But I’m starting to see a strengthening of the foundry again, as there is another phenomenon going on. 8-inch capacity is being obs
componenttext:
Well, I think what we would have seen would have been a weakening in the foundry, with a strengthening in the NAND Flash. But I’m starting to see a strengthening of the foundry again, as there is another phenomenon going on. 8-inch capacity is being obsoleted left and right. You’ve got company after company who have been operating inefficient 8-inch fabs. And with the downturn, they’ve made decisions, we’re getting out of the fab business, and there is tremendous amount of 8-inch and even 6-inch silicon that’s been being produced and is now going to jettison itself into 300-millimeter granted older technology line within the foundry. But I think that’s a phenomenon you see play out. We see approximately five - the equivalent of 550K wafer start - 300-millimeter wafer start factories needing to be put in over the next five years to absorb all of this what I would call inefficient 300-millimeter silicon, with systems whereby the clock to maintain them is becoming much higher than if people could make the transition in the foundry.
So I think people are starting to see that. It’s gone critical from the standpoint of there is not a critical mass to sustain that equipment and it’s got to move to 300. I think that’s going to help the equipment business over the next five years with a few more extra fabs going in. So I don’t see foundry slowing up. I, in fact, see the NAND coming in along with foundries remaining pretty solid. There are over 40 8-inch fabs that have been decommissioned in the downturn. And if you do a simple math, divide it by 2.25, that’s saying there is a lot of fabs that have to be put in place to pick that capacity up or at least capacity. It’s going to fill excess capacity and they are going to put in some additional capacity for that. Okay. Thank you very much.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Great. That was very helpful. Can I just come with a follow-up? Just quickly on your bookings, you talked about second half being up compared to the first half, but given that you are up 20% this quarter, up, let’s say, 5% in the third quarter, that wou
componenttext: Great. That was very helpful. Can I just come with a follow-up? Just quickly on your bookings, you talked about second half being up compared to the first half, but given that you are up 20% this quarter, up, let’s say, 5% in the third quarter, that would suggest that 4Q could be down possibly in bookings. Is that how we should think about that 4Q booking and -?

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, hi, thanks. Question on the foundries, it seems like there was a little bit of a slowdown and you are seeing a little bit of a re-acceleration. I wanted to drill into that a little bit more. There are some concerns on Q4 semiconductor wafer shipments
componenttext: Yes, hi, thanks. Question on the foundries, it seems like there was a little bit of a slowdown and you are seeing a little bit of a re-acceleration. I wanted to drill into that a little bit more. There are some concerns on Q4 semiconductor wafer shipments for the foundries. Does that have anything to do with what’s happening there? There's also been some thoughts that lithography capacity is constrained at the foundries and perhaps that’s driving it. Or is it a fact - is it due to customer mix where one customer has slowed but a new set of foundry customers are starting? What’s sort of driving that little perturbation of the foundries?

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it’s largely additional foundries coming on and bringing on capacity and trying to accelerate and pull in their generation of capacity. And certainly, there are some hot gadgets that are hitting the market that are also driving expansion o
componenttext: Well, I think it’s largely additional foundries coming on and bringing on capacity and trying to accelerate and pull in their generation of capacity. And certainly, there are some hot gadgets that are hitting the market that are also driving expansion of the capacity.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay.
componenttext: Okay.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Relative to the slowdown, I think lithography has been mentioned in many analyst reports as potentially a limiter going forward. I think on the very, very leading edge of technology, there’s probably some truth to that. But I think there is also a growt
componenttext: Relative to the slowdown, I think lithography has been mentioned in many analyst reports as potentially a limiter going forward. I think on the very, very leading edge of technology, there’s probably some truth to that. But I think there is also a growth in the older technologies, as I’ve articulated as 800 - as 200-millimeter factories are decommissioned. But in addition to that, I think even in the core heart of the market at 65-nanometers, there is substantial expansion that’s available there as well.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-12-2010

componenttext: All right. That’s very interesting. Couple of quick things on 22-nanometer. Do you see any meaningful orders starting to get placed for 22-nanometer? When do you expect that to ramp? On the model, what should we model for share count in Q3? Thanks.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-12-2010
componenttextpreview: I think in 22-nanometer you’d see substantial amount of technology investment at this particular time, not a lot of production capacity at this time. And as we get closer and closer to zero, one person’s 22-nanometer is not another person’s 22-nanom
componenttext: I think in 22-nanometer you’d see substantial amount of technology investment at this particular time, not a lot of production capacity at this time. And as we get closer and closer to zero, one person’s 22-nanometer is not another person’s 22-nanometer. So there is a lot of subtleties at 22 nanometers and beyond. And I don’t think we have solved all the technical hurdles yet. Okay?

componenttext: Okay, got it. And last question, Rick, I think I ask you this every single quarter, but I’m still trying to figure out how the OpEx has barely gone up in six quarters when the revenue has gone up so much. And I guess I’m trying to figure out whether - maybe headcount has come down a little bit. Are you actually eliminating some headcount? So if you could give us an idea of how much headcount has changed in the last six months that might explain how you are keeping OpEx so flat.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, in fact, our headcount actually grew in the last quarter. Our headcount went up. But we are doing a lot of things internally from the standpoint of our efficiency. As we’ve highlighted before, we have in-sourced operations in both India and Vietna
componenttext:
Well, in fact, our headcount actually grew in the last quarter. Our headcount went up. But we are doing a lot of things internally from the standpoint of our efficiency. As we’ve highlighted before, we have in-sourced operations in both India and Vietnam. We’ve become extremely adept at utilizing those resources. Okay? And as a consequence, you will see an unprecedented number of products introduced here. I talked about our R&D productivity has gone up tremendously. And I think it’s due to the model that we have operating-wise. We use a worldwide labor force, both from a standpoint of we start on West Coast and we finished in Europe. And I think we’ve also been very targeted on where we are putting our evaluation units and the customers that we are focused on from a marketing standpoint.
I think John and his team have done a phenomenal job on the SG&A side, bringing that down. I mean, I don’t know what to say to you other than we have made a lot of investments over a long period of time and we are delivering on those investments as well. And as such, we did reduce headcount last year, but we haven’t taken out any material headcount. There is a slight drift upward, but not a major drift upward at this point in time. But there is clearly a utilization of lower cost, high technology headcount throughout the company by all organizations. And I think that’s helping our wage structure, and as a result, our overall operating expenses.

componenttextpreview: Great. And then with regard to this newly introduced product for the wafer level packaging and through-silicon via and so forth, as you introduce these new products in gain for the penetration, should we expect the gross margin to improve or decline? What
componenttext: Great. What’s your best guess right now?

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Our best guess is our model is remaining the same. Our target is 52% to 54%. As someone pointed out, we haven’t reset yet. It’s a tough slug in a very, very competitive market. But we think with the productivity and the reliability and simplicity that
componenttext: Our best guess is our model is remaining the same. Our target is 52% to 54%. As someone pointed out, we haven’t reset yet. It’s a tough slug in a very, very competitive market. But we think with the productivity and the reliability and simplicity that we have in this new platform, there are not only the applications that we are launching today, but numerous other applications that can be applied to this platform. And we think it can be a big, big productivity gainer in many areas in the wet processing within the fabs. And I think those that attend this afternoon will get a little bit of a flavor for that.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-12-2010
componenttextpreview: In this effort, do you expect the OpEx to increase as a result, I mean, as you’re trying to push into these new markets? Or should we expect OpEx to pretty much trend along as it has in the past few quarters?
componenttext: In this effort, do you expect the OpEx to increase as a result, I mean, as you’re trying to push into these new markets? Or should we expect OpEx to pretty much trend along as it has in the past few quarters?

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Well, there are two ways to utilize OpEx. People fund a [ph] program and when the program is done, you move them into the next program. That’s been our operating model. We’ll continue to do so unless we feel like we’re starving a program in which ca
componenttext: Well, there are two ways to utilize OpEx. People fund a [ph] program and when the program is done, you move them into the next program. That’s been our operating model. We’ll continue to do so unless we feel like we’re starving a program in which case we will selectively increase R&D in given area. As long as revenue continues to grow, it gives us an opportunity to have more dollars to spend. And we’ll bring those up slowly as to make sure that we don’t get too far in front of what is a sustainable business. We want our model to be profitable, both in the upturns, and as you can tell, it’s become very, very profitable. And we wanted to maintain profitability within the downturn. And as a consequence, we got to make sure that we don’t build in too much fixed cost infrastructure. And so our ability to be productive in our R&D is a key - one of our key objectives going forward is to figure out how we leverage worldwide knowledge, skills and ability to make our R&D more productive than anybody else’s in the world.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you so much.
componenttext: Great. Thank you so much.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-12-2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, Rick, thanks so much for taking the questions and congratulations on the really strong profitability. Two questions. One kind of macro; one micro. First on the macro side, as you had discussions with the executives of your customers, how are they thin
componenttext: Hi, Rick, thanks so much for taking the questions and congratulations on the really strong profitability. Two questions. One kind of macro; one micro. First on the macro side, as you had discussions with the executives of your customers, how are they thinking about just all of the macro cross currents? I mean, you said before you have to run the business as if the sun is going to come up every morning. But what are your customers saying or, more importantly, doing in relation to a lot of the noise that’s happening in Europe and China and elsewhere?

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-12-2010
componenttextpreview: I think they are all cautious from the standpoint of their worry that demand in Europe is going to cease and that somehow that’s going to have a negative impact on their business. So they are cautious. But one of the things in these conversations that w
componenttext:
I think they are all cautious from the standpoint of their worry that demand in Europe is going to cease and that somehow that’s going to have a negative impact on their business. So they are cautious. But one of the things in these conversations that we find is that the place that demand is really the strongest and the most surprising is in China and in developing nations. Now, it has its set of problems associated with it because it tends to be on the lower end of technology, but it’s rapidly pushing up into the high end of technology.
And clearly, with this push to strengthen the RMB, that does nothing but help people with high technology, selling high technology into the Chinese market, because by having strengthening RMB, their ability to buy the best technology and have it sealed just like it’s a local cheap technology, they can get better for the same amount of money. And I think that’s a factor that’s playing into what’s going on today. I think as that market matures, like everyone else and everywhere else, people want very, very high quality goods. You know, you see the success Apple is having worldwide. I think that’s happening with another number of companies on a smart phone aspect. I think from the standpoint of personal computer technology, that’s becoming pervasive even in developing countries. I think those are all good fundamental building blocks to strong end demand over the next couple of years.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-12-2010
componenttextpreview: That’s helpful. Thank you. And if I could just follow up on the micro side, are you having any discussions with your customers about them looking for additional clean room space that they are worried about if demand continues to grow, they are going to
componenttext: That’s helpful. Thank you. And if I could just follow up on the micro side, are you having any discussions with your customers about them looking for additional clean room space that they are worried about if demand continues to grow, they are going to run out of clean room space in order to bring in more equipment or is that not part of the equation just yet?

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-12-2010
componenttextpreview: There are still some empty fab shells that need to be filled, of course. And I think you will see those being filling over the next 12 months. I think that the key today is density of output. The fact is if you’ve got highly productive dense output mach
componenttext: There are still some empty fab shells that need to be filled, of course. And I think you will see those being filling over the next 12 months. I think that the key today is density of output. The fact is if you’ve got highly productive dense output machines, that enables customers to really monetize their factory and output more wafers within a given factory. And we are benefiting in some areas particularly well from this. And we think that’s going to continue for a while. But you are going to see new factories building in China. There is a new factory that’s going to go in 300-millimeter in Shanghai with Huali. That’s going to be going in. So I do see Greenfield fabs are starting to come into play. And it’s a matter of at what point do they pull the trigger. And obviously, with construction down in a lot of places, the ability to put a fab up in nine months is the reality today when that used to be a year-and-a-half - a year to a year-and-a-half at some other regions. So my expectation is the next leg up for this, you will see more groundbreaking. And I think that’s what you are looking for.

componenttext: We do not see an inordinately high number of turns business. Our lead times are in the 12-week to 16-week area. We manage that with our customers who maybe in the end, by the time you get the order and ship the product, it might be minus one week lead time. But the reality is, you know the customers, you know their - their word is extremely good, and you have a history of convention of how do they business. But I think in general, we’re really looking from a time when we know the business is going to occur, we usually have at least 12 weeks, if not 16 weeks, ahead of the game.

componenttext: Yes, good afternoon. Thank you for taking my question. I guess, Rick, first question, when you look at the Greenfield fabs that are coming on line, can you talk about how that has changed your visibility today and how that compares to, say, three months ago?

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-12-2010
componenttextpreview: I don’t think there is any change relative to Greenfield fabs that are coming on that has changed our thinking. I think we have a handle on where they are likely to occur, what’s the driving force behind them. Unfortunately, as we’ve seen in the pas
componenttext: I don’t think there is any change relative to Greenfield fabs that are coming on that has changed our thinking. I think we have a handle on where they are likely to occur, what’s the driving force behind them. Unfortunately, as we’ve seen in the past, you can have a Greenfield fab and you can put the walls up and you can leave it empty for a couple of years. I don’t think that’s the desired mode of ramping a fab, but we’ve seen that happen in the past. So we’ve basically planned based on predicting how many wafers needed to produce in order to be able to fill what we believe is end electronics demand. And that’s what drives our whole model internally.

componenttext: Welcome to the Novellus Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. As a reminder this call is being recorded October 26, 2010. I would now like to turn the conference over to Ms. Robin Yim of Novellus Systems. Please go ahead.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you operator. Good afternoon and thank you for joining the Novellus Systems third quarter earnings conference call. With me today on the call in San Jose is Rick Hill, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and John Hertz, our Chief Financial Officer
componenttext:
Thank you operator. Good afternoon and thank you for joining the Novellus Systems third quarter earnings conference call. With me today on the call in San Jose is Rick Hill, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; and John Hertz, our Chief Financial Officer is travelling and joining us remotely.
Financial results for the third quarter were released on PR Newswire shortly after 1:00 p.m. Pacific Daylight Time. You can obtain a copy of the news release in the Investor Relations section of our website at novellus.com
Today’s earnings call contains forward-looking statements about Novellus’ business outlook, the future performance of Novellus and our products and forecast of key metrics for the fourth quarter of 2010. Specific forward-looking statements include, but are not limited to our forecasted bookings, shipment volume, revenue, gross margin, operating expense, tax rate and earnings per share. Our expectations regarding the additional stock compensation expense resulting from changes in our stock plan, expectations regarding growth and endeavors in 2011, anticipated global semiconductor utilization levels, general economic trends and trends within our industry and market, and other unanticipated future events.
We caution you that forward-looking statements are projections and expectations regarding future events. They involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from the results contemplated, including an inaccurate basis for our financial forecast.
Information concerning risks that could cause actual results to differ materially is contained in today’s press release, and our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, including our Form 10-K for fiscal 2009, our Form 10-Qs for the first and second quarters of 2010, and our current reports on Form 8-K.
During our call today, we will make references to non-GAAP financial measures, which exclude certain charges, benefits, and other items, which are detailed in our earnings release. For reconciliation of non-GAAP to GAAP financial measures, please refer to our website at novellus.com and our earnings release and our Form 8-K furnished to the SEC today. We do not provide a reconciliation of the forward-looking non-GAAP to GAAP measures because of our inability to project certain charges, costs and expenses. Forward-looking statements are based on information as of today, and we assume no obligation to update any such statements.
John Hertz will begin today’s call with a review of the financial results for the third quarter. Rick Hill will then discuss the state of the business, followed by guidance for the fourth quarter of 2010, and then we will open up the conference call for the Q&A session.
Now I will turn the call over to John.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Robin, and good afternoon everyone. I’m pleased to announce another outstanding quarter where we met or exceeded our guidance and continue to improve operating leverage and maintain strong cash flow generation.Before I get into the specific
componenttext:
Thank you, Robin, and good afternoon everyone. I’m pleased to announce another outstanding quarter where we met or exceeded our guidance and continue to improve operating leverage and maintain strong cash flow generation.
Before I get into the specifics, I’d like to preface my comments by stating that throughout the rest of my remarks I will be distinguishing between GAAP and non-GAAP results. The non-GAAP results exclude a total of $5.1 million of charges primarily related to the consolidation of the Switzerland [ph] Industrial Applications Group manufacturing facility into Germany. I’ll refer to them collectively going forward as other items. A detailed breakout of these items, by type is included in today’s press release.
So with that, third quarter 2010 bookings came in at $407 million, up 6% compared to the second quarter and slightly above midpoint of the guidance range, which was flat to up 10%.
As a result of increased business levels, third quarter shipments were $363 million, up 9% for the second quarter. Shipments also finished near the midpoint of our revised guidance range at $355 million to $375 million. Third quarter revenues were $367 million, up 14% over the second quarter, which came in just above the high end of our revised guidance range of $345 million to $365 million. Our third quarter revenues by geographic region are as follows. United States 22%, Greater China 36%, Korea 31%, Japan 4%, Europe 7%.
Third quarter gross margin on a GAAP basis was 49.1%, excluding $2.5 million in other items, gross margin came in at 49.8% in line with the midpoint of guidance. Third quarter operating expenses totaled $91 million on a GAAP basis, excluding $2.6 million and other items and non-GAAP operating expense were $88 million for the quarter. Our data model and increased our operating margin from 22.8% to 25.8% quarter-over-quarter. Other came in as an expense of $132,000. We had approximately $1 million of net interest income, which was offset by approximately $1.1 million of net, unrealized foreign exchange losses due to currency fluctuations and impact on the U.S. dollars held offshore.
The third quarter tax rate without other items was approximately 14%. We now expect our fiscal 21 effective tax rate, excluding discrete items, to be approximately 15% and specifically for the fourth quarter, the tax rate expected to be approximately 14%.
Net income for the third quarter on a GAAP basis was $76 million or $0.82 per fully diluted share excluding $5.1 million in other items, net income on a GAAP basis was $81 million or $0.88 per fully diluted share, [Inaudible] high-end of revised guidance range of $0.80 to $0.90.
Moving to the balance sheet, we ended the quarter with $786 million in cash. Short-term investments, restricted cash and long-term investments, which is up $43 million from the $743 million ending balance in the prior quarter and up from $713 million at the beginning of the year. Cash flow from operations in the third quarter was $82 million and for fiscal 2010 year-to-date, it is $248 million. Net income for the quarter included non-cash charges for depreciation and amortization of $9 million and stock compensation of $9 million.
Additionally, CapEx for the quarter was $6 million. In the quarter, we use $38 million to repurchase approximately 1.6 million shares of stock on an average price of $24 under our authorized stock repurchase program. Approximately, $643 million remains authorized for repurchases under our stock repurchase program, which expires in October 2011.
Accounts receivable in the third quarter, increased by 30% to $199 million as a result of increased shipment levels. And our DSO came in at 49 days, which is slightly better than our ongoing target range of 50 to 60 days. Inventory increased at modest 1% over Q2 despite the continued growth in shipment levels, this is attributed to improved inventory controls, order management and forecast accuracy. Inventory turns improved quarter-over-quarter and came in at 3.8 times, up from 3.5 times in Q2.
So in summary, Q3 was another outstanding quarter from the financial results perspective. Our operating leverage improved, and cash generation remains robust. Before I turn the call over to Rick, I would like to point out that during the fourth quarter, we modified our equity compensation plan to provide certain retirement benefits. As a result of this modification, we expect to incur approximately $10 million of additional stock compensation expense in the fourth quarter. That concludes my remarks.
Now, I’ll turn it over to Rick who will comment on the state of the business, followed by fourth quarter guidance for our key financial metrics.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. It’s nice to report another great quarter of operating results, and as John just outlined in his discussion, we continue to execute on our financial model with increased profitability and strong cash flow generation of $82 million in th
componenttext:
Thank you, John. It’s nice to report another great quarter of operating results, and as John just outlined in his discussion, we continue to execute on our financial model with increased profitability and strong cash flow generation of $82 million in the quarter. In addition, as he reported, in the quarter we purchased 1.6 million shares at an average price of $24 per share. And that brings our share count down to I believe approximately 91 million shares outstanding. And we leave the quarter with very, very strong cash as we ended the quarter, so we feel very, very good about that.
Now with that, I would like to update you on the business environment and then provide guidance for our fourth quarter. For 2010, we benefited from the PC refresh cycle, also enterprise storage utilizing a solid-state hybrid architecture, which is stimulated demand for NAND flash and a robust smartphone market for growth.
Now according to third party estimates, growth for 2011 is looking to see the same demand drivers, including the introduction of new competitive to the iPad tablet products. Additionally, as we said in the past, we don’t believe the current communications infrastructure is sufficiently robust enough to support the growing demand for mobile graphics and video, both domestically and in the emerging Asian markets and therefore we expect to see the continued gentrification of the worldwide internet infrastructure.
And lastly, the information technology applications were used in defense and intelligence have room for a significant improvement and further proliferation. So we continue to believe the necessary demand drivers to feel growth for our business long-term remain intact. Closer to our capital equipment business as we expected global semiconductor utilization levels through the September quarter remain very high at an average of about 97%. This is largely been due to under investment in the previous years and continued growth in the use of integrated circuits in almost every application, consumers need today.
Quarter four utilization is expected to be in line with seasonal level in the 90 plus percent range, which is a trigger point for continued investment. Now our expectation for annual semiconductor revenue growth of 30% to 35% in CapEx growth of approximately 100 plus percent in 2010 remains unchanged. The current unstable macroeconomics for the general economy and weakening in memory prices could potentially impacts some of our customer’s profitability and potential their forecasted levels of investment in the short-term, but the long-term remains very solid.
With that here is the guidance for the fourth quarter. We expect bookings to be from up 10% to down 14%. This large range is due to the timing of our customers’ projects and an unstable macroeconomic situation along with concerns with tax laws and governmental spending that’s worrying people for private investment. Our shipments are forecasted to be up sequentially, between 5% to 13% to $380 million to $410 million.
Our revenue is forecasted to be flat, up 5% or $367 million to $385 million. This is the result of market share gains and newly won product positions with the customers. As you may have noticed, shipments are forecasted to increase in the quarters. And revenue does not track directly and that is because the timing of acceptances and the required revenue bifurcation under our revenue recognition policy is causing a revenue lag for the new customers. We have the requirement of having two systems accepted in new applications at our customer base. So this is why the revenue and the shipment don’t track directly.
Our growth margin is forecasted to be 50% plus or minus 1%. Our GAAP earnings per share is forecasted to range from $0.73 to $0.88 and on a non-GAAP basis between $0.85 to $1.00.
That concludes my comments and guidance for the fourth quarter. And now I would like to open it up for any questions you may have.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much. (Operator Instructions) We’ll take our first question from Satya Kumar with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Thank you very much. (Operator Instructions) We’ll take our first question from Satya Kumar with Credit Suisse.

componenttext: And Rick, I guess at the mid-point your guiding bookings to be down. And I think one of your peers talked about seeing some shipments getting pushed out from the December into the March quarter. As you look into the first half of next year, how do you think the year is going to sort of shape up related to bookings and shipment trends as you see from your customers right now?

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, right now I’m trying to go through the fourth quarter. And one of the things we believe as we had forecasted at the beginning of 2010 is the first half would be up over the second half would be up over the first half in 2010. Depending upon what h
componenttext:
Well, right now I’m trying to go through the fourth quarter. And one of the things we believe as we had forecasted at the beginning of 2010 is the first half would be up over the second half would be up over the first half in 2010. Depending upon what happens from a standpoint of elections and taxes, and how the market holds up through the year. If the market holds up and these tax cuts are made at least temporarily extended, I think that will bode well for end demand.
But if the tax law isn’t extended, these tax breaks are not extended, and we see a great dip in the market as a result, because I do think the market is forecasting that the tax cuts will be extended. That would make people not feel very wealthy and it could adversely affect the potential for 2011. So I think a lot of hinges in the next few weeks, and I think the mid quarter update will get a better feel for our customers on whether they are going to get bullish or remain tentative on their investment levels. But right now I think people are tending to be tentative because there is so much uncertainty, and that’s globally, not just in the United States.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

componenttext: Thank you.

componenttext: Good afternoon. Thank you for taking my question. I guess two questions. The first one in terms of that the orders guide there it seems to be a little bit wider than norm for you guys. So I guess, curious what’s driving the concerns that are on timing and I guess is it primarily foundry related, any color you could provide, that would be great?

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well at year end, we have tried to adapt a stance that our products have value and we’re not going to try to book something to make numbers a given way. And so when there are ordering profiles that hinge on the end of the quarter, we want to state the o
componenttext: Well at year end, we have tried to adapt a stance that our products have value and we’re not going to try to book something to make numbers a given way. And so when there are ordering profiles that hinge on the end of the quarter, we want to state the obvious, and that is if they fall in the quarter, it could be better, and if they fall outside of the quarter then maybe the quarter doesn’t hit what our expectations were. But I think in addition to that there truly are macro uncertainties of which we can’t control that are also playing into effect here, and whether or not people continue to be bullish if the wrong outcome happens here in the next few weeks that remains to be seen and we can’t forecast it. So that’s why it’s a little wider.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I guess thinking longer-term in terms of your strategic focus, I was just comparing where are you guys are at today versus just eight or nine quarters ago and you’ve basically doubled your net income at basically the same revenue line ite
componenttext: Okay. And then I guess thinking longer-term in terms of your strategic focus, I was just comparing where are you guys are at today versus just eight or nine quarters ago and you’ve basically doubled your net income at basically the same revenue line items, so kudos to you on that front. So I guess my question to you is what are you going to do for non-core? Is the focus in terms of cash harvesting mode or do you plan to invest for growth and if so how do you balance I guess those two things?

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well we have continued to invest for growth. I mean we haven’t made enormous cuts in our R&D, although we have cut some R&D as programs have materialized and they have been very, very successful. As I have stated before I think the next main driver over
componenttext: Well we have continued to invest for growth. I mean we haven’t made enormous cuts in our R&D, although we have cut some R&D as programs have materialized and they have been very, very successful. As I have stated before I think the next main driver over this next year is going to be NAND Flash. In order for NAND Flash to be a really huge driver there has to be leaps and its performance capability. And I think 2011 could see some dramatic improvements in cost per bit on NAND flash. And we believe that we have technology and capabilities that we worked on for a long time. And we believe that we could be seeing these things being adopted during 2011 and that will be part of our non-core. Okay.

componenttext: Thank you.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I mean obviously we’ve had some very, very strong growth in 2010 and the question becomes how quickly can that capacity be digested and that clearly is a function of end demand. End demand is the function of the confidence of the consumers in the market
componenttext:
I mean obviously we’ve had some very, very strong growth in 2010 and the question becomes how quickly can that capacity be digested and that clearly is a function of end demand. End demand is the function of the confidence of the consumers in the market, and that’s global consumers.
If I had to make a statement right now, I think global consumers are relatively strong. Corporate consumption has been relatively strong, globally now I’m talking about, not just in the United States, obviously, United States it’s been more muted from a consumer standpoint but not very, very weak. And if there is confidence that the markets are stable, I think at these levels people feel as though they have wealth. So to the extent the financial markets can remain stable, I think that we’re going to have a good first and second quarter.
It would be tough, I mean, I couldn’t name all of the bookings at this point in time. I am just giving you how I read the tea leaves when I look at what’s going on macro economically. But having said that, there is a lot of uncertainty and so it’s very, very difficult to project the first and second quarter. But I don’t see it falling off; I don’t see us having a 2009 end of 2008 phenomenon happening unless there is a financial melt up. So that’s the best I can give you on how I am thinking.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great. That was great color. Thank you.
componenttext: Great. That was great color. Thank you.

componenttext: Got it. And looking forward into 2011, among all your product groups, which product do you think have the highest probably not the potential, but actual probability of gaining more market share? If the CVD, PVD which one would you say?

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think our SABRE-3D product is a homerun and I think from a standpoint of the backend TSV, if you are talking percentage growth, it’s going to have the greatest because it’s starting from the smallest number. But I think we’ll see good contin
componenttext: Well, I think our SABRE-3D product is a homerun and I think from a standpoint of the backend TSV, if you are talking percentage growth, it’s going to have the greatest because it’s starting from the smallest number. But I think we’ll see good continued growth in the PVD business and also some of the breakthroughs that we’ve developed from a PECVD market despite the tremendous growth they’ve seen we think that, that growth will continue into next year. Overall, the only product where growth is tough to come by is HDP and we are working on new technologies to make it extendable, but fundamentally people are groping for technologies for FDI and the PMD layer for 22 nanometers and beyond. And it’s tough to solve it with the existing HDP technology, but we do have some exciting innovative technologies that we are trying to bring to market.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks Rick.
componenttext: Thanks Rick.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

componenttext: And moving on, we’ve question from Jim Covello with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, Rick. Thanks so much. I appreciate it. The question, you talked about how you think NAND is going to drive a lot of the growth going forward. Are you saying that kind of in the near-term views with your customers as well where NAND is a little bit hea
componenttext: Hi, Rick. Thanks so much. I appreciate it. The question, you talked about how you think NAND is going to drive a lot of the growth going forward. Are you saying that kind of in the near-term views with your customers as well where NAND is a little bit healthier than DRAM? And then my follow-up would just be within DRAM, are you seeing any difference at all between what maybe a Tier 1 DRAM company would be looking at as we head into next year versus some of the Tier 2 and Tier 3 guys who are definitely struggling right now, or is DRAM just weak across the board? Thank you.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the strong are getting stronger and the weak are getting weaker and that will be a function in the capital markets. And I think the capital markets have become more efficient, the ability to be able to get capital if they don’t think they can su
componenttext:
I think the strong are getting stronger and the weak are getting weaker and that will be a function in the capital markets. And I think the capital markets have become more efficient, the ability to be able to get capital if they don’t think they can succeed is a lot more limited and so that war is against the weaker DRAM players. I think the strong DRAM players have extremely impressive technology and it’s going to be hard for the Tier 2s to catch up although if they can find the available cash, it is possible to do. So I think you will see continued investment in the Tier 1 and you will see selective investments in the Tier 2.
Relative to NAND Flash, my expectation is you will see and again as just trying to look into my crystal ball and looking past tomorrow is hard enough. But I think 2011 is going to bring some pretty significant technological advances in NAND Flash technology that are really going to make its viability as the mainstay of non-volatile memory a reality. And I am excited about the future. That’s not to say that there aren’t technological hurdles, but this industry has a way of always solving them.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much.
componenttext: Thanks very much.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Rick, I am just curious here now that you are seeing pretty good market share gains across the board. When you start to throw a little bit more R&D weight and potentially when you would see more pressure to get R&D back at the kind of 60 millio
componenttext: Thank you. Rick, I am just curious here now that you are seeing pretty good market share gains across the board. When you start to throw a little bit more R&D weight and potentially when you would see more pressure to get R&D back at the kind of 60 million per quarter clip. I’m especially thinking about projects that we really haven’t heard that much about lately like PVD, at what point of the cycle do we start to throw some more R&D way behind that and when you think that will occur? And do you think that’ll get us back to this 60 million kind of run rate for R&D?

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well I don’t see that on the near horizon because I see a more focused R&D strategy. About 5 or 6 years ago, we sort of went away from our focused R&D strategy and we threw a lot of systems out into the marketplace. And that didn’t prove to be effecti
componenttext:
Well I don’t see that on the near horizon because I see a more focused R&D strategy. About 5 or 6 years ago, we sort of went away from our focused R&D strategy and we threw a lot of systems out into the marketplace. And that didn’t prove to be effective with our culture. We’ve fixed that problem over the last several years. We’re operating in a mode today where we very strategically target the technologies and move forward. Now one investment on the horizon, although from everything we can see at this juncture, the economics of it are still questionable. 
But at some point in time, there will be investment levels at 450. But now they’re at pretty nascent levels, but I can anticipate those growing probably in the latter part of 2011 and maybe into 2012.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just a quick follow-up here, Rick I think this question may have been asked in another form, but you guys have done an amazing job in terms of showing earnings leverage. But on a top line, on the revenue growth perspective year-over-year, you’
componenttext:
Okay. And just a quick follow-up here, Rick I think this question may have been asked in another form, but you guys have done an amazing job in terms of showing earnings leverage. But on a top line, on the revenue growth perspective year-over-year, you’re pretty much in line with your industry for 100% year-over-year growth for your total revenue. 
I don’t want to get into discussion between the break-out of semi-industrials, but what do you think is going to drive your semi business to outgrow the market more meaningfully in 2011?

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it clearly has to be expansion in the NAND market. And I think there are technological opportunities and technological demand that if we can deliver on it, it can bring both unprecedented costs per bit as well as clearly technology different
componenttext: Well, I think it clearly has to be expansion in the NAND market. And I think there are technological opportunities and technological demand that if we can deliver on it, it can bring both unprecedented costs per bit as well as clearly technology differentiable capability to a market from an equipment company. And I think that’s the real opportunity going forward.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. Thank you.
componenttext: Okay. Great. Thank you.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: There was a comment earlier on the call that the memory prices following discussing some of your forecasts from some of your customers to come down potentially. Is that what is claiming to be wide range of guidance for Q4?
componenttext: There was a comment earlier on the call that the memory prices following discussing some of your forecasts from some of your customers to come down potentially. Is that what is claiming to be wide range of guidance for Q4?

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. Not really. We just highlighted that we watch the memory prices. So, we’re basically regurgitating what I think you guys already know that if the ASPs on memory drops below a level of which someone can make money at, they’re not going to add capac
componenttext:
No. Not really. We just highlighted that we watch the memory prices. So, we’re basically regurgitating what I think you guys already know that if the ASPs on memory drops below a level of which someone can make money at, they’re not going to add capacity for it. We’re not at that level in the new technologies; some of the older technologies we are. 
Well in the short term what will happen is that capacity will come offline and there’ll be an increased investment in the next technology in order to get your cost down but that isn’t what’s causing the wide band and bookings of orders, it is the fact that we’re not going to just try to ram orders in here at the end of the year to make things look good, and two: there’s a lot of macroeconomic uncertainty. I think that’s true even in your guidance business.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. As a follow-up, some of your peers have gone ahead and given some color on the outlook for the first half of next year? Is there something else you can add to your comments so far as to what you expect for first half and going into next year?
componenttext: Okay. As a follow-up, some of your peers have gone ahead and given some color on the outlook for the first half of next year? Is there something else you can add to your comments so far as to what you expect for first half and going into next year?

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well I sort of articulated it a few minutes ago that if the markets stay stable, up over 11,000 here, I think the average individual feels like they’re okay and they have wealth and to the extent they feel that way, the fundamental end demand is going t
componenttext:
Well I sort of articulated it a few minutes ago that if the markets stay stable, up over 11,000 here, I think the average individual feels like they’re okay and they have wealth and to the extent they feel that way, the fundamental end demand is going to continue to be strong. There are major decisions that are going to be made between now and the end of the year relative to taxes that are greatly going to influence both the consumer and also corporations on their decisions for investment. 
A huge tax increase at this juncture, I believe is not priced into the market. If there was a huge increase AKA the bush tax cuts expire, then I think that, that will greatly cause people who are tentative to hold back their investment and that is from the consumer standpoint all the way to a corporate standpoint. So I think that uncertainty is what’s giving us the wide birth in the order outlook.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you.
componenttext: Okay. Thank you.
