headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks for taking my question, Rick. Two questions. First is, after 2011, I wanted to find out how do you see the non-flash spending in terms of first half of ‘11 versus the second of ‘10. And as a follow-up, I wanted to find out compared to the prior
componenttext: Thanks for taking my question, Rick. Two questions. First is, after 2011, I wanted to find out how do you see the non-flash spending in terms of first half of ‘11 versus the second of ‘10. And as a follow-up, I wanted to find out compared to the prior cycle on NAND, how much of share gains have you accomplished that you think you might be benefited going forward in ‘11 if non-spending is going to be up is going to be up? Thank you.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, so I think the first question is how do I look at first half NAND demand versus second half and I think it’ll continue to accelerate throughout the year. There will be some NAND expansion in Q1 and Q2 and then I believe you’ll begin to see major
componenttext:
Okay, so I think the first question is how do I look at first half NAND demand versus second half and I think it’ll continue to accelerate throughout the year. There will be some NAND expansion in Q1 and Q2 and then I believe you’ll begin to see major new investment in advanced technology in the latter half of the year. 
So I probably think that, that sort of plays itself out. I think that as the technology transition happens with NAND flash to new advanced technologies, I think that we will see an ever-increasing share of Novellus products in the majority of NAND flash products. We believe some of our products are clear enablers for advanced technology. So that’s just a general feeling.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Mehdi Hosseini with Susquehanna.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Mehdi Hosseini with Susquehanna.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks for taking my question. I have two. Rick if you could elaborate on the capital intensity between NAND and DRAM and how do you see that changing going forward? And I have a follow up.
componenttext: Yes, thanks for taking my question. I have two. Rick if you could elaborate on the capital intensity between NAND and DRAM and how do you see that changing going forward? And I have a follow up.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: The NAND intensity…
componenttext: The NAND intensity…

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Versus DRAM.
componenttext: Versus DRAM.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: So by NAND intensity or capital intensity are you talking about their capital percent of revenue investment? In other words the number of dollars in..
componenttext: So by NAND intensity or capital intensity are you talking about their capital percent of revenue investment? In other words the number of dollars in..

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was actually referring to millions of spending required for one increment of 1K per month added. For example I’m under assumption that for NAND it would take $20 million to $25 million to add 1K increment of additional capacity that compares to 30 to
componenttext: I was actually referring to millions of spending required for one increment of 1K per month added. For example I’m under assumption that for NAND it would take $20 million to $25 million to add 1K increment of additional capacity that compares to 30 to 35 or even higher for DRAM. What do you think about those numbers that I gave you and how do you see that capital intensity changing going forward?

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I’m not hesitating because I don’t want to answer your question. I’m just not quite sure how to address your question. So capital intensity we’ve typically always said okay for $1 of investment how much revenue do you get out, right? And
componenttext:
Okay. So I’m not hesitating because I don’t want to answer your question. I’m just not quite sure how to address your question. So capital intensity we’ve typically always said okay for $1 of investment how much revenue do you get out, right? And so the amount of equipment you need stays pretty constant to increase capacity but as the ASP comes down, even though we try to increase throughputs it’s tougher, you see an increasing capital intensity from that perspective. I think with NAND flash there’s a wider profit margin on NAND flash right now so its capital intensity is perceived as being lower.
I think that what you will find is as the next generation of technology comes out, the cost per bit will be so attractive. You will get a much greater acceleration in the unit demand and therefore, the key to success in this next generation is going to be not only the quality of the films but also the throughput of the films and that’s why I think it’s such a great opportunity for Novellus and I think we’ll rise to the occasion and really help enable that next generation of NAND technology that will make it viable to replace a bigger segment of hard disk drives with solid state memory. 
And so that’s how I look at it. And so the bottom line is, ASPs will come down in NAND flash and that capital intensity will appear to go up but from an actual amount of equipment that’s used, employed to build a NAND, there’s not a huge amount of difference. I hope that helps? I hope I’m answering the question you asked?

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Moving on to my second question, I’m just trying to understand the thought process behind your commentary on the tax cut or the Bush tax cut and not sustaining going forward. I look at Novellus and look at the current environment tax rate of 15 to
componenttext: Sure. Moving on to my second question, I’m just trying to understand the thought process behind your commentary on the tax cut or the Bush tax cut and not sustaining going forward. I look at Novellus and look at the current environment tax rate of 15 to 20% back in early last decade. It was much higher but capital equipment spending was taking place so usually Novellus is an example for the rest of the tech industry, especially for your customers based in the U.S. I am not sure how to reconcile your comment with the spending pattern, and I am just wondering if there is something else behind your comment that we need to pay attention?

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. It’s a good question, and let me try to clarify. So from a bush cut standpoint that the consumer, okay. You’re going to have a large tax bite despite the way everybody spends it, the amount of disposable income people will have will be dramatica
componenttext:
Okay. It’s a good question, and let me try to clarify. So from a bush cut standpoint that the consumer, okay. You’re going to have a large tax bite despite the way everybody spends it, the amount of disposable income people will have will be dramatically less if those are repealed. So that’s one element of it. 
Going along with those tax changes are recommended tax changes for corporation, then as you highlight it, the Novellus effective tax rate has dropped dramatically over the last few years, and that has been accomplished because for a long time our business has been moving to Asia and more and more of our sales are in Asia. We modified our structure to take advantage of the tax laws that allow us to pay the taxes in the area from where our product is being delivered and as a consequence, our effective tax rate is lower.
Now, part and parcel to what’s being contemplated is to remove all those tax benefits, and I’m sure you’ve heard of all these, I know you’re very in tune with that. And what’s going to happen is if all of those opportunities to really match our revenue in the region we’re in with the tax structures in the region, our tax rates would go up dramatically, and all those would have an adverse effect on investment. And so that’s what I’m talking about. And I just sort of blended them all together. So I apologize for that.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Got it. Thanks so much.
componenttext: Got it. Thanks so much.

componenttextpreview: Alright.
componenttext: Alright.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Also, one area where I think you guys have been waiting for some improvements and increases on the PVD side of things. I guess two-part question. When do you see, I guess, an inflection point for increases in your PVD share? And secondly, what will
componenttext: Okay. Also, one area where I think you guys have been waiting for some improvements and increases on the PVD side of things. I guess two-part question. When do you see, I guess, an inflection point for increases in your PVD share? And secondly, what will be the, I guess, the key factor or facet that drives improved share in your PVD business?

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: So, PVD is a technology play from a standpoint of, its enabler is technology. 2010 was a big up year in PVD for us and we are happy with it, but it’s a long way from where we want it to be. The big enabler is basically 32 and beyond, because of our abil
componenttext:
So, PVD is a technology play from a standpoint of, its enabler is technology. 2010 was a big up year in PVD for us and we are happy with it, but it’s a long way from where we want it to be. The big enabler is basically 32 and beyond, because of our ability to be able to really void-free fill and provide extremely high aspect-ratio seed for subsequent layers of Electrofill. And we also see its expansion capability into both TSV and the overall packaging market.
So I think those are the key things that we’re looking for and we just keep hammering away application by application, but I think we’ll see another very, very good year in 2011 for PVD growth.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you.
componenttext: Great. Thank you.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: What’s the right cash that you need to run your business? I mean, I sort of look at the buyback and I see that it came way down and there is still lots and lots left even at this velocity. So what is the cash you need to actually run your business?
componenttext: What’s the right cash that you need to run your business? I mean, I sort of look at the buyback and I see that it came way down and there is still lots and lots left even at this velocity. So what is the cash you need to actually run your business?

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, it depends upon how fast we grow, of course, and obviously to the extent we have fun working capital, we need more cash. And the other aspect of it is, what is the volatility of the industry going forward? Obviously, we were very lucky from the stan
componenttext: Well, it depends upon how fast we grow, of course, and obviously to the extent we have fun working capital, we need more cash. And the other aspect of it is, what is the volatility of the industry going forward? Obviously, we were very lucky from the standpoint of the amount of cash we had available to us during the last downturn, it enabled us to do some things others couldn’t do and I think you will see some of the weaker companies who have burned through their cash even during the downturn. But I think that the level that we are at is probably a couple hundred million given our current revenue levels than we would need. If we doubled our revenue, I think our cash would be perfect but if our revenues don’t double, half isn’t sufficient either.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I guess just the kind of bottom-line it, so if the business were to not grow from here not that it well or it won’t grow but if it were to grow, then you have a couple hundred million dollars of extra cash?
componenttext: Okay. So I guess just the kind of bottom-line it, so if the business were to not grow from here not that it well or it won’t grow but if it were to grow, then you have a couple hundred million dollars of extra cash?

componenttext: Okay. And then just last thing from me, I asked you about three months ago, I think I asked you where your model was at $400 million and you said that your gross margin would be between 52% and 54%. And if I use kind of a 70% drop through from kind of your guidance in Q4 up to 400, you are at 51, so you are still like 200 basis points shy of that model. Is there some mix issue in there?

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, there is certain Peter Wolters is weighing heavily on that at the corporate level, right, so that I have to fix and part of the consolidation we went through is an attempt to get out some of that. And we are also working at doing some other things r
componenttext: Well, there is certain Peter Wolters is weighing heavily on that at the corporate level, right, so that I have to fix and part of the consolidation we went through is an attempt to get out some of that. And we are also working at doing some other things relative to the industrial business, but that’s the toughest part of our problem.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Are most of the tools that you are selling in the foundry segments were leading edge or are you seeing any incremental demand from not so leading edge at the foundries?
componenttext: Are most of the tools that you are selling in the foundry segments were leading edge or are you seeing any incremental demand from not so leading edge at the foundries?

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we are seeing demand at both the leading edge and in fact the very, very trailing edge. As there is -- one of the things we have described before is the fact that last downturn has caused corporations that have their own internal very small
componenttext: Well, I think we are seeing demand at both the leading edge and in fact the very, very trailing edge. As there is -- one of the things we have described before is the fact that last downturn has caused corporations that have their own internal very small inefficient fabs that had to invest every year a small amount of money to say forget it, I don’t want this facility any longer. And there is been an acceleration to the foundries, well, much of that technology is a 130 nanometer technology or 110, okay. And as a result, we are seeing some demand today for putting in 300 millimeter fabs with that technology now.

headline: Novellus Systems, Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And is that type of demand coming from Tier 1 type foundries or Tier 2? And how do you see that types of demand as we look into next year?

componenttext: Well, clearly, I think if you look at the expansion in China, there is been a large amount of demand in that particular area. And but I don’t think it’s just relegated to mainland China, its other areas as well.

componenttext: Well, I would like to thank all of you for joining us today. I am sorry; the call was a little bit late. There has been a lot of travel going on here around at Novellus and unfortunately we had to postpone our conference call a week later than we like to. We appreciate your support in Novellus. We look forward to speaking with you at our mid-quarter update which is going t come around really quickly given how late we are with this announcement. And also again talking with you in January for our year-end conference call. Thank you very much and thanks especially for your support of Novellus.
